Text1: My community engagement experience impacted in my learning about diversity because working and volunteering in a community engagement class and volunteering was a way to know and be more empathic with people from different background. It was a great way to expand my knowledge about diversity.
Text2: The way this class impacted my attitude about the ways in which I engage in my local communities is to be more socially confident and to be more self aware of the place I come from.

Text1: My experience opened my eyes to just how impactful it is to understand each other and the burdens one may be facing.  It is important to realize that even though we may all come from different backgrounds, we all hurt the same and need support healing.
Text2: This class changed my perspective on community service and engagement.  It made me realize that your actions no matter how big or small will make some kind of impact.  It takes so little effort to really engage with your community, but it could make a huge difference in someone else's life.

Text1: Community engagement has always allowed to me to become more involved and excited about learning. By working in a community that I am not familiar with, I get to diversify my knowledge and learn what it means to be from different geographical and ethnic backgrounds.
Text2: This class is my third community engaged/service learning course and with each that I take I feel that I become more and more passionate about working within communities of color, specifically hispanic and Mexican/Chicano communities since that is how I identify. This class has only excited me more to pursue my minor in Community Engagement and Social Change which I was just accepted into this quarter! I look forward to interacting with more community leaders, activists, and community members in general.

Text1: it showed me that there is a genuine fear from others when a group of people (especially poc) get together and try to get more rights. there is also power in solidarity when you support a cause that perhaps might not affect you directly.
Text2: I feel more confident in the fact that i have a better idea on what to do in order to bring change in issues that i care about.

Text1: I was able to tutor young students who were from a lower income community. This allowed me to expand my knowledge and experiences outside of the Orange county bubble that I live in.
Text2: I became more open minded after taking this class. I learned more about the community and learn about the different deep routed issues within the community and the ways that I could try to fix them. I had no idea about upstream thinking or how to proceed with finding the root cause of the many inequalities there are in the world today.

Text1: I do not think my community engagement impacted my learning about diversity that much. It was online volunteering, so I wasn't meeting new people or learning anything in person. While I gained a lot from the experience, learning about diversity wasn't necessarily the largest impact the course and my engagement had on me.
Text2: I would say it impacted my attitude in a bittersweet way. I now am aware of a multitude of ways to serve and engage in my local communities that concern issues in our society. However, I am now aware of countless more issues that I previously did not know about. This certainly stresses me out, and makes me feel small and powerless when it comes to change. However, I am very glad I had to the opportunity to serve my community again and I plan on trying to continue my work with Food Oasis because it is not very time consuming but also makes me feel connected to real change.

Text1: It made me much more aware of the issues that are so prevalent in LA neighborhoods and the United States as a whole, specifically on racial injustice.
Text2: I now know that I need to look upstream and engaging with others is very important because it empowers us to make lasting changes in our society.

Text1: Helped me look past stereotypes of communities that I had. Made me think more about how there the reality of a community can be much different than what everyone on the outside thinks of them. This is why community engaged work is important because the community themselves knows what's best for them and their needs.
Text2: I found the importance of targeting upstream conditions/root causes. My organization targeted a very limited audience with their downstream conditions and it felt like we weren't doing anything.

Text1: It helped me learn more about the communities that require help and how input from diverse communities is essential.
Text2: It made me learn more about the techniques essential for this and ways to get the community involved.

Text1: Broadening my knowledge of the kinds of resources available in LA. There are many places/organizations that are available for people.
Text2: Moving forward I acknowledge that everyone has a story and to humanize everyone I interact with no matter what kind of community they come from. In LA I'm more aware of the different pockets of communities which allows me to integrate backgrounds and histories that make up these areas. In return I can better engage better overall.

Text1: My community engagement experience forced me into an environment with diverse faces and backgrounds of the Latinx community. Communication with the community was a struggle to to my limited capacity to communicate in Spanish, but overall being exposed to such new perspectives and understandings of the world made me understand the needs, desires, and overll how rich these communities are.
Text2: I feel like my past experiences have already enabled me to approach and engage with local communities in ways that are open minded and have no notions of savior/superiority complexes. After my service learning, I feel like my attitude has shifted even more to be able to appreciate communities for all they have to offer and to view community needs as something that must be approached from an equity standpoint.

Text1: My community engagement experience impacted my learning about diversity in an indirect way since it was remote, but still allowed me to feel like I was having a part in helping to mitigate the effects of a social inequality issue. I have a deeper understanding of the scope of food insecurity and a better perspective on how many people are suffering from this issue as well as the type of people who are more at risk of suffering. I thought the community engagement work supplemented the lecture material well and demonstrated the connectivity of social inequality issues as it relates to diversity.
Text2: My experiences in this class impacted my attitude about the ways to engage local communities by showing me it is easier to engage local communities than it seems and making me more passionate about community-engaged work. I have a better understanding of social inequality issues and with this education, I see the importance and benefit of engaging local communities and the variety of ways to do so. Whether the work relates to upstream causes or downstream effects, is remote or hands-on, I understand that it is all vital in moving towards a more just world.

Text1: For me I think community engagement experiences can provide rich opportunities to meet and learn about people of different cultures, backgrounds and perspectives from varies countries around the world.
Text2: Developing a suitable curriculum that avoids imposing Western knowledge while educating immigrants and refugees is crucial for fostering cultural inclusivity and respect. Additionally, cultivating a sense of responsibility among individuals is  important as well.

Text1: This course allowed me to learn about the community of South L.A., which I previously did not know much about other than the fact that it is economically disadvantaged. Being able to engage with community leaders and promotoras de salud (community health workers) was truly awe-inspiring because I could feel their passion for their community and see how much work they dedicate to it.
Text2: It taught me the importance of humility and active listening. I understand the importance of academic researchers having humility when reaching out to a community organization so that they can actually be helpful for the community, rather than hurtful.

Text1: My community engagement experience exposed me to diverse communities in the South Central LA area that have a range of perspectives, traditions, cultures, and values. By working with these groups, I now have a deeper understanding of the importance of considering/including standpoints and experiences that differ from my own.
Text2: My biggest takeaway is that it's vital for community members to be considered part of the team as much as people like students and researchers. Bidirectional relationships, fostered by active listening and open lines of communication, are essential for engaging local communities and promoting sustainability.

Text1: I learned about the value of understanding different identities and experiences which can formulate the diversities in communities. This can also help build trust in communities and community members can look up to individuals who have has similar trajectories and adversities.
Text2: I learned about the importance of allowing community members to voice their opinions and concerns to allow for maximum engagement as well as trust. Community leaders should take measures in effectively asking questions and engaging with their local communities by hosting events that facilitate a support system and create liaisons across various programs.

Text1: Why I was already familiar with how diverse Los Angeles was, I learned that in order to make any form of social change in the region, we must take diversity into account. This means looking at intersections of race, gender, religion, ethnicity, etc. Different social groups face different barriers, so it is important to see how different obstacles affect different people to create better solutions.
Text2: I have never volunteered much before this. Working with my community-based organization, I realized just how easy it was to get yourself involved in the community. Opportunities to help are everywhere. You can even work in your own space online. I found it very refreshing.

Text1: I believe that in terms of diversity, society has been conditioned to see different social concepts, such as race, gender, social class, etc as black and white. Although all of these are socially constructed and are often a product of unjust power dynamics, my community engagement experience has taught me that overlooking them altogether and pretending like they do not exist (ex. being "colorblind") does not work to solve the root of social injustices. The only way to work towards social progress is to acknowledge the impacts these social terms disproportionately have on different groups of people, for both agent and target groups. My partner organization, Mar Vista Family Center, for example, allowed me to see first-hand the different ways in which these disparities shape the opportunities and privileges that a population might lack. Celebrating diversity comes with acknowledging the role these dynamics play in access to opportunities and embracing the importance of cultural identity.
Text2: From this class, I have learned that although community engagement may be done on a local level, the social injustice that the work targets is often one that spans social disparity and power dynamics working on a structural, global scale. Because of this, there is no one specific way of working towards a solution. With food insecurity, for example, seeking change through food banks and distribution helps to alleviate local stress for disadvantaged families around. However, upstream solutions target disparities lying at the foundation of these issues---ones that can only fully be resolved by acknowledging the overarching inequities and histories that accompany them. From this, I have learned to be more aware of how crucial this acknowledgement it is and the ways in which it goes hand in hand with different forms of activism in the community.

Text1: It really makes you think about how structural racism plays a huge role in all of our communities and opens your eyes to the injustices of redlining and related practices.
Text2: It encouraged me that change is possible!

Text1: I was exposed to new concepts and methods of communication that I hadn't previously experienced. I feel a lot more prepared to enter my field -- beyond just having the knowledge required to work in biomedicine, being able to effectively and ethically do research is something I want to center in my work.
Text2: It made me realize how important, and necessary it is Community engagement is not some optional thing that only some people need to learn -- I think these concepts should be required for students in my field.

Text1: Further emphasized importance of diversity, makes me grateful to have this education and be apart of an institution and emphasizes diversity.
Text2: The main takeaway is looking at upstream issues in the community. This analogy changed my way of thinking about these social issues occur and how to help solve them.

Text1: Having grown up next to the community I volunteered for I already felt a sense of understanding of the issues they faced. Therefore, as I returned to the community I didn't feel as if I was entering an unfamiliar community and learning about their values for the first time. Nonetheless, even in the past 5 years, the El Sereno community has changed significantly, with the predominantly Latinx community shifting to a more ethnically diverse community. Therefore, upon returning, I learned about the necessity to educate these new community members the importance of these resources which are a response to systematic  attacks against this historically Latinx community.
Text2: My experience in this class has shown me that no act is too small. It is in our communities that we can begin to change the world around us, and although it may appear a futile act at times, the act of helping just one other person is extremely impactful.

It also opened my eyes to different forms of community engagement beyond just volunteering or NGO work-- especially with research.

Text1: At my community engagement site I worked with people with a variety of educational backgrounds, ethnic and cultural backgrounds, socioeconomic standing, and employment goals. I learned about how people with the highest educational achievements and degrees to their name are not necessarily the ones that employers are quick to hire, because there are systemic barriers to employment that deter people with mental disabilities, people from stereotyped groups, people with criminal records, etc from being employed.
Text2: I learned to not approach local communities with a savior mindset, but rather working with communities to hear their proposed solutions and the needs that they see in their community. I also learned to play an active and engaged role, to take the initiative to ask about people's lived experiences.

Text1: I wouldn't say that my community engagement experience impacted my learning about my diversity. My work revolved around people with my same background--low-income Latino communities. It was rewarding to go back to my roots and help out those who needed it in Eastside Los Angeles.
Text2: My attitudes changed entirely. Growing up, no one in my community was really involved in local politics and fighting for improvements. My city had a history of corruption; doing anything felt hopeless. Through my work at InnerCity Struggle (ICS), I learned about the type of changes organizations could make via education. ICS did a wonderful job with community outreach and reminding people in Eastside LA about their housing rights. I won't be as complacent with mediocre politicians anymore.

Text1: I was able to learn about how diversity can bring different life experiences for people. Race and other characteristics can define how people are seen by the world and how they see world.
Text2: I think this experience made me realize that there are many different ways to engage with my local community. It does not have to be doing the things most people think of like volunteering at food banks. My job was mostly remote, but I made flyers and blog to help market an organization that makes significant change in the community and it was a different, yet still valuable, experience for me and the community.

Text1: I learned that in some organisations there isn't much diversity which can be due to its reduced values, goals, and campaigns.
Text2: I feel more prepared to engage with my local communities but also understand why they are being targeted and impacted negatively.

Text1: My community engagement experience allowed me to witness firsthand the different systemic and social issues faced by diverse communities that are not prevalent in mainstream media or knowledge. It allowed me the opportunity to understand the types of solutions and visions that members of different communities have, as it is very specific to the types of issues they are particularly fighting for (or against). It has made me more open-minded and allowed me to understand specific social justice issues from various different perspectives.
Text2: My experience in this class impacted my attitude in the sense that I place more emphasis on culturally conscious methods of community engagement, because often times what we perceive as 'helpful' may not necessarily align with the actual needs of the affected communities. This quarter has strengthened my desire and dedication to incorporating the voices of different communities into my social engagement work, as the goal of community engagement and service is not to speak over marginalized communities, but give them a platform to share their voices and actualize ideas for change.

Text1: As I worked alongside my community partner, I learned that diversity is a complex subject. While many individuals come from distinct backgrounds, in large cities like Los Angeles, they may be facing similar issues and inequities. However, diversity can also be applied as a driving factor to explain why some individuals and populations face specific social injustices while others do not. Therefore historical context and insight by members of a community are key to truly comprehending the role of diversity in any context.
Text2: Even though I knew there existed flaws in our nonprofit and social equity sector, I did not understand what caused their efforts to be ineffective nor how to address them. My attitude towards community engagement changed as I gained insight into these questions through the class curriculum. Instead of mindlessly supporting and providing aid to known, established nonprofits, if we truly want to create change, we must research their approach and activities behind the scenes. Moreover, we must advocate for combating upstream conditions by working directly with community members and their strengths.

Text1: Through community engagement, I have the opportunity to engage in meaningful interactions and conversations with people from diverse backgrounds. I can learn firsthand about the traditions, customs, languages, and values of different cultures, challenging preconceived notions and stereotypes.
Text2: In the past, I haven't ever noticed the importance of engaging with local communities. This class rise my awareness and interest to make contributions to local communities and I will definitely volunteer in some community organizations this summer.

Text1: I learned about people from many different racial and ethnic backgrounds as well as experiences and different areas of Los Angeles. I was exposed to many people who are different than me, and I learned about their diverse experiences.
Text2: I learned upstream approaches to engaging local communities rather than downstream approaches or utilitarian approaches. I think upstream approaches are really important as they can allow for more effective and permanent solutions rather than a quick fix.

Text1: My community engagement experience impacted my learning about diversity by allowing me to see the intersectionality that exist amongst the communities impacted by social issues.

Text1: While pouring my heart out to young children with different backgrounds and ages, I hoped for their well-rounded growth. I also had the opportunity to confront and seriously contemplate the dark realities of the United States. As a result, this class has been helpful in fostering respect for diversity, understanding others, and improving communication with them.
Text2: I realized that the responsibility for solving societal problems lies not with politicians or others, but with myself. As a result, I have developed a deeper interest in local community news and have engaged in self-reflection on the role I play as a member of society.

Text1: My community engagement experience impacted my learning about diversity in various ways. I would say that the biggest way it impacted my learning would be by making me increasingly aware of the various circumstances that my peers may be going through. Particularly with my volunteering experience, I found that while individuals seem to be doing well both physically and mentally, their stories that they create tell a different perspective to them and their lives. I believe that it was initially hard to look past the exterior personalities and stories of individuals and my volunteer experience has allowed me to look further into individuals.
Text2: I would say that my experience in this class impacted my attitude about the ways to engage my local community because it made me more proactive. As it opened my eyes to the greater issues that are often hidden, it allowed me to be unable to ignore these issues as well. Now that I am more aware, it is easier to find opportunities to fight for change in particular issues such as lack of education and homelessness.

Text1: My community engagement experience provided me with behind-the-scenes mechanisms needed to confront environmental injustices in low income communities of color. I was able to observe how nonprofit organizations can change policy through activism as well as legal intervention. I was able to work with individuals from different backgrounds and experiences. This allowed me to step out of my comfort zone, and see firsthand how it is that environmental injustices are affecting different folk's long-term health.
Text2: This class introduced me to distinct literary works. One of my favorites being that of Laura Pulido's LAttitudes editorial, addressing the underlying racism and colonialism that continues to influence contemporary society. Capitalism has created this misleading and predatory idea of "disposable groups of people." This class allowed me to challenge this narrative and apply what I have learned about social justice to help low-income communities. Most importantly this class has allowed me to learn more about my own community and the environmental injustices such continues to face.

Text1: During my time volunteering at Food Forward, I had the chance to truly understand the value of diversity. I met and worked with people from various cultural, racial, and socioeconomic backgrounds. Each person brought their unique experiences, values, and perspectives to the table, enriching our collective experience. Interacting with diverse community members, especially those facing socioeconomic challenges, fostered empathy and compassion within me. It wasn't just theoretical knowledge I was gaining; it was real, firsthand experience with the complexities and richness of diversity. This engagement had a profound impact on me, fundamentally changing how I perceive and value diversity.
Text2: Before I began participating in social engagement activities, my perspective on community involvement was rather limited. I understood its value in principle, but didn't truly comprehend its depth and impact. However, my experiences transformed my understanding in profound ways. Volunteering at a local food bank was my first step into active community engagement. I realized that many people living in my own neighborhood were struggling with food security, something I'd previously been unaware of. This opened my eyes to the hidden realities many of my fellow community members face and spurred me to action. Through these experiences, my attitude shifted from passive resident to active community member. I learned that every contribution, no matter how small, can make a difference. I now see that change begins at home, in our local communities, and I'm committed to continuing my efforts to make a difference right where I am.

Text1: I was able to work with a community from outside of the country in Mexico, it focused on working with them to have a sustainable life while they are in the process of transitioning into living in the U.S. I am a Mexican-American but I have never been to Mexico myself, so there was a lot to learn about the people who are living there and their experience as transitioning into essentially stateless people. My parents are also immigrants but came 20+ years ago, so the situation for crossing illegally was a lot safer than it is now. I learned that isn't the reality anymore and the rates of people coming in have gotten higher and higher and it has become even more difficult and difficult. So I think now I am more aware of the different walks of life that people go through despite us having similar backgrounds. I am also a lot more aware of BIPOC in my own community which is usually not spoken about in Latino Communities.
Text2: It made me a lot more open to thinking that I am actually able to go out into communities and especially my own and try to be more a part of them. I think there was a lot of fear that I was in when it came to engaging with anyone really. But now I have more confidence and a positive attitude toward learning more about people and their backgrounds.

Text1: Working with a group of 6 other people with such diverse experience and knowledge, I realized how much each person could contribute to help create an impactful project. We also got to travel to Azusa, CA where the demographic population is much different than my hometown. I attended diversity and community engagement working group meetings and saw a diversity of faces. Each person had a different specialty but came together to better the community. Overall, my community engagement experience allowed me to see the value in diversity.
Text2: Honestly, before I took this class, I never felt involved in a community to the extent where I felt like there was potential for long term change. This class broke down the theoretical and how to actually apply principles of community engagement that will actually work. Engaging my local community now seems more feasible.

Text1: It was very eye-opening.
Text2: It made me understand the way my experiences affect the way that I feel in society.

Text1: I was able to participate in a healing retreat that works with people who deal with trauma. The people who came were predominantly Black, so I got to hear their voices and stories which taught me about their culture and beliefs.
Text2: I really enjoyed going to this retreat. I found it inspiring, insightful, and heart-warming to listen to others share their difficult experiences. Being able to be amidst their vulnerability and authenticity made for such a fulfilling time.

Text1: My community engagement experience impacted my learning about diversity because it showed me how there are many forms of diversity, it wasn't just limited to race or gender.
Text2: My experiences in this classes greatly impacted my attitude about the ways to engage my local communities. Before, one of the reasons i was hesitant to get involved in something was because I didn't know what to do to make a difference. Now with new knowledge like theory of change, I know how to apply them in the real world.

Text1: Through my community engaged learning, I was able to expand my understanding of how diversity functions in LA. Although the city is incredibly diverse, it does not provide for each of these diverse perspectives in an equitable way. Communities of color are far more likely to have worse life outcomes than white individuals in wealthy areas. My project helped me understand how community engagement can help to create a more equitable environment for all people.
Text2: This class taught me that there are more effective ways to help people than donating money. Obviously, money is an important component of social change but it can only go so far. To create positive change, one must approach engagement through an asset-based approach. By acknowledging community norms, individuals are more likely to create lasting change because their programs are catered to the individuals that they serve.

Text1: My community engagement experience had a profound impact on my understanding of diversity. By actively engaging with the community and working closely with individuals from diverse backgrounds, I gained firsthand insights into the richness and complexity of human diversity. Through my interactions with community members, I learned to appreciate the value of different perspectives, experiences, and cultural backgrounds. I realized that diversity encompasses not only visible differences such as race, ethnicity, and gender but also a wide range of identities, beliefs, values, and experiences.
Text2: Prior to taking this class, I had a limited understanding of the various approaches and strategies for community engagement. However, through the course material, discussions, and practical exercises, I gained valuable insights that transformed my perspective. This class emphasized the importance of building genuine relationships with the local community. I learned that effective community engagement goes beyond a one-time interaction or a top-down approach. It requires establishing trust, active listening, and collaboration with community members to understand their needs, aspirations, and concerns. This understanding influenced my attitude towards community engagement, as I now prioritize relationship-building and the establishment of mutual respect and trust.

Text1: I learned more about the Los Angeles community's diversity and the disparities between affluent and low-income communities. Many low-income communities have very diverse backgrounds, including people of color or older individuals, who are often not involved in decision-making processes that affect them.
Text2: Getting feedback from the community is important in determining the best strategies for addressing issues locally. People within a community know what they need the most.

Text1: In SoLa I was able to engage with students younger than myself and learn about what they want to do and understand the reasons behind whether they want to go to college as people who grew up in LA. Through Sereno Community Land Trust I learned about the hard work that many workers go through in planting and taking care of crops, something I was familiar with but had not done myself.

Text1: I feel like my community engagement experience impacted me in teaching me the extent to which we can have diversity in our communities. I saw students from different types of ethnic backgrounds at the volunteer slots I signed up for, and I really enjoyed being able to help them foster their skills. I also learned more about how diverse LA was, specifically in the Mar Vista area. It was really interesting to see how the outside world changed when I would take the bus from Westwood to mar vista, and I recognized these differences on my first day in person. I feel like I definitely see the Westwood bubble that people talk about and even though my own neighborhood back in South Central looks completely different to Westwood, it was interesting to see other parts of LA being diverse as well.
Text2: I feel like I've learned that to really be engaged in the community, you need to work from the inside out and approach things as an ally to the people who are already doing the work. I think it taught me more about seeing people in their leadership roles and helping them achieve their goals because they are at the center of the change they're trying to make. In this way, you work with the community and can be a valuable asset to a team. It puts a lot less emphasis on the "individual savior" complex and reminds us to take on an asset-based approach to engagement.

Text1: I learned that people are a lot more diverse and come from a lot of different backgrounds outside my neighborhood back home and at UCLA. I learned to not judge others because they are different or because they are in a less fortunate situation than me. I learned the importance of helping others, even if it means sacrificing something of my own.
Text2: I learned that there were multiple ways to engage with my local communities. I also learned the ideals in forming relationships with community partners and the strategies to use that would be the most effective. The main takeaway I had from this class is to trust the community partners more and take their word for most things because they know their communities the best.

Text1: I think being able to reach outside this sort of "bubble" I sometimes find myself during my time here in Westwood, a place that feels far removed from many underserved communities, has been very fulfilling. Working with my community partner, I've learned that people who need aid, specifically mental health resources, come from all walks of life and socioeconomic degrees, and working with my non-profit organization has revealed the diversity of issues that BIPOC individuals deal with daily that aren't being addressed.
Text2: I've always felt this tenacity to get more involved in organizations that directly help underserved communities, and being in this class has immensely amplified my drive to invest my time/efforts in providing resources for the communities around me. In psychology specifically, I want to focus my future work on marginalized communities where mental wellness is heavily stigmatized, and this class has helped me learn where I can get started in this venture.

Text1: Diversity past race and ethnicity is very important. It’s easy to umbrella people that are Hispanic and Latino. In the case of Esperanza Community Housing their differences in language, in home country, in skills, in past careers, in education are what truly makes Esperanza diverse. Diversity needs more than one or two criteria. To effectively make change, represent ,and engage a community we need to take the time to invite all walks of diversity rather than what meets the eye.

Dissecting frameworks and case study’s allows not only for a more structured approach to community engagement but receipting on areas of improvement. There is no one right way to engage a community rather it’s more specific and catered to the specific issue etc. It is really an every changing process and I learned to keep that mindset.

Text1: My community engagement experience of working with PILAglobal helps me to learn diversity regarding refugees/alyssums/immigrants. Cause before this project, I was doing research that will seldom be shared back to the needed population. But this experience taught me to focus on the communities’ real needs, and doing projects like this can not only help me learn a new topic but also can be applied and used in new life when immigrants first moved to the U.S.

The program that I worked with had me engage with kids from these areas, which led to a considerable amount of reflection, as childhood is at the core of every person.

I believe it has made me more likely to engage in similar work in the future.

Text1: Before this class, I felt like I was in a bubble and I never really took the time to learn more about the city I live in and the space I take up. Taking this class has helped me realize my own privileges and stereotypes that occupy my thoughts, as well as how I contribute and am a product of social inequality as white-passing woman. I feel like I have a much wider view of the world and a better understanding of the systemic inequalities in place that has contributed to the world I know.
Text2: I feel like I have a lot more empathy understanding communities outside of my own, especially non-Asian, non-white people, those with disabilities, and the unhoused population. I haven't had much exposure to these populations outside of this class and I am very grateful for it.
